author: alexssd7fp
content:
Geth people, a question to you.

Talking about the recently discovered difficulty adjustment algorithm flaw. TL;DR it is exploitable as you can artificially lower the block timestamp to have *a bit* higher difficulty and thus be able to have a higher TD. That gives an ability to make a single-block reorg on top of the blockchain for no cost no matter when you actually mined the block and cause other miners' block to become an uncle. This is a massive problem as malicious miners can steal high MEV blocks from other miners and improve their uncle rate while suffering honest miners' rates.

Suppose more and more pools incorporate this to defend against F2Pool attacks. In that case, it will cause the mainnet difficulty to quadruple and increase block times by many times, significantly damaging the UX.

I think it can be fixed easily by just disallowing single-block reorgs on top of the current chain. Would a fix like this introduce issues?

author: sky.cactus
content: Changing fork choice to disallow single block reorgs will just make two block reorgs more common.  Also, with PoS around the corner, changing PoW algorithm doesn't seem like a good use of time, we can just launch PoS early if things break rather than trying to craft a fix.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, block times wouldn't increase in any sustained way I don't believe.  At most there may be a brief adjustment period.

author: polandia94
content: I think you always could artificialy low the timestamp (and because of that we dont use timestamp as random value). But there is a cost, you have to actually mine a block on top the n-1 block before another mine n+1, and dont necesary have more reward (fees or mev) than build on top of n(the natural form to do)
